title: 2 Kings Chapter 15 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Kings chapter 15 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Kings Chapter 15 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Kings Chapter 15.

questions.question: At what age did Azariah son of Amaziah begin to reign as king of Judah?
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:2 states that Azariah was sixteen years old when he began to reign.

questions.question: How many years did Azariah reign in Jerusalem?
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:2 tells us Azariah reigned two and fifty years (52 years) in Jerusalem.

questions.question: What was the name of Azariah's mother?
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:2 names Azariah's mother as Jecholiah of Jerusalem.

questions.question: What disease did the LORD inflict on King Azariah?
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:5 says the LORD smote Azariah so that he was a leper until the day of his death.

questions.question: Who was made over the king's house to judge the people when Azariah was afflicted?
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:5 states that Jotham the king's son was over the house, judging the people during Azariah's affliction.

questions.question: How long did Zachariah the son of Jeroboam reign over Israel?
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:8 reports Zachariah reigned six months over Israel in Samaria.

questions.question: Who conspired against and killed Zachariah?
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:10 tells us Shallum conspired against Zachariah, struck him down, and reigned in his stead.

questions.question: How long did Shallum reign as king of Israel?
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:13 states Shallum reigned a full month in Samaria.

questions.question: What terrible act did Menahem commit at Tiphsah?
options: He ripped open all the women with child
questions.correctAnswer: He ripped open all the women with child
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:16 records that Menahem smote Tiphsah and ripped open all the women who were with child.

questions.question: How many years did Menahem reign over Israel?
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:17 says Menahem reigned ten years in Samaria.

questions.question: True or False: Pekahiah reigned over Israel for two years.
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:23 states Pekahiah reigned two years over Israel.

questions.question: True or False: Pekah was killed by Hoshea the son of Elah.
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:30 records Hoshea conspired against Pekah, killed him, and reigned in his place.

questions.question: True or False: Jotham removed the high places during his reign.
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:35 explains that the high places were not removed during Jotham's reign; people still sacrificed and burned incense there.

questions.question: Complete this verse from 2 Kings 15:4: 'Save that the ______ were not removed: the people sacrificed and burnt incense still on the high places.'
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:4 states that the high places were not removed and sacrifices continued there.

questions.question: Complete this verse from 2 Kings 15:19: 'And Pul the king of Assyria came against the land: and Menahem gave Pul a thousand ______ of silver.'
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:19 says Menahem gave Pul a thousand talents of silver to confirm his kingdom.

medium.title: 2 Kings Chapter 15 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Kings Chapter 15 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with physical suffering and isolation. Based on Azariah's experience in 2 Kings 15, what biblical truth would you share about perseverance through trials?
options: God may allow trials but remains sovereign and worthy of trust
Physical suffering means God has abandoned you
You must isolate yourself completely in suffering
Trials are punishment without hope for healing
questions.correctAnswer: God may allow trials but remains sovereign and worthy of trust
questions.explanation: Azariah was struck with leprosy and lived in isolation (2 Kings 15:5), yet he continued to reign and his son judged the people, showing God's sovereignty and faithfulness even in hardship. This teaches perseverance through trials with trust in God (2 Kings 15:3, 15:6, 15:7).

questions.question: How does Azariah's reign teach us about faithfulness despite incomplete obedience?
options: He did right in the Lord's sight but did not remove high places
He did evil and led people into sin
He completely obeyed God and removed all high places
He ignored God's commands and served other gods
questions.correctAnswer: He did right in the Lord's sight but did not remove high places
questions.explanation: Though Azariah did what was right like his father Amaziah, he did not remove the high places, and the people still sacrificed there (2 Kings 15:3-4). This shows believers can be faithful yet still have areas needing growth, encouraging humility and perseverance.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to compromise in their walk with God. Based on the kings of Israel in 2 Kings 15, what warning does this chapter give about departing from God's ways?
options: Departing from God’s commands leads to evil and downfall
God blesses compromise to keep peace
Sin is acceptable if others do it
questions.correctAnswer: Departing from God’s commands leads to evil and downfall
questions.explanation: Kings like Zachariah, Menahem, Pekahiah, and Pekah all did evil by continuing sins of Jeroboam (2 Kings 15:9, 15:18, 15:24, 15:28), leading to conspiracies and downfall (15:10, 15:14, 15:25, 15:30). This teaches the importance of obedience and integrity in daily life.

questions.question: How does Menahem’s payment to the king of Assyria in 2 Kings 15 teach us about stewardship and the consequences of political alliances?
options: Menahem extorted wealth from people to pay tribute, showing poor stewardship
Generosity always leads to God's blessing
Trusting worldly powers is the best way to secure your future
Paying tribute guarantees peace without cost
questions.correctAnswer: Menahem extorted wealth from people to pay tribute, showing poor stewardship
questions.explanation: Menahem exacted heavy taxes from Israel’s wealthy to pay Assyria (2 Kings 15:19-20), illustrating that reliance on political powers can lead to injustice and poor stewardship, contrasting with biblical generosity and trust in God.

questions.question: What does Jotham’s reign teach us about humility and contentment in spiritual growth despite incomplete reforms?
options: Jotham did right but did not remove high places, showing partial obedience
He fully reformed the nation and removed all sin
He led the people astray completely
He ignored God’s commands and worshiped idols
questions.correctAnswer: Jotham did right but did not remove high places, showing partial obedience
questions.explanation: Jotham followed his father Uzziah’s example and did right before the Lord (2 Kings 15:34) but the high places remained (15:35). This teaches believers to be content with progress in obedience while still striving for deeper spiritual holiness.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Kings 15, all the kings of Israel mentioned fully obeyed the LORD and removed the sins of Jeroboam.
questions.explanation: Multiple kings such as Zachariah, Menahem, Pekahiah, and Pekah did evil and did not depart from the sins of Jeroboam (2 Kings 15:9, 15:18, 15:24, 15:28). This shows ongoing disobedience and failure to fully obey God’s commands.

questions.question: A believer is struggling to forgive those who have wronged them. Based on the conspiracies and killings of kings in 2 Kings 15, what biblical insight about forgiveness and reconciliation can you share?
options: Unforgiveness and conspiracies lead to destruction and instability
Seeking revenge is the best way to maintain peace
Violence is a godly response to betrayal
questions.correctAnswer: Unforgiveness and conspiracies lead to destruction and instability
questions.explanation: Several kings were killed by conspiracies (2 Kings 15:10, 15:14, 15:25, 15:30), showing how unforgiveness and violent responses cause chaos. The passage teaches humility and love for neighbors to maintain peace and fellowship.

questions.question: How does the reign of Azariah and his son Jotham illustrate the biblical principle of parenting with wisdom and spiritual leadership?
options: Jotham took over judging the people during Azariah’s illness, showing faithful passing of responsibility
Parenting has no impact on spiritual leadership
questions.correctAnswer: Jotham took over judging the people during Azariah’s illness, showing faithful passing of responsibility
questions.explanation: Azariah’s leprosy caused him to dwell separately, and his son Jotham was made ruler over the house and judged the people (2 Kings 15:5), demonstrating the importance of raising children in godly leadership and responsibility.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "The LORD said to Jehu, 'Thy sons shall sit on the throne of Israel unto the ___ generation.'"
questions.explanation: God promised Jehu that his descendants would rule Israel for four generations (2 Kings 15:12), showing God’s faithfulness to His covenant and His sovereignty in leadership.

questions.question: What does the destruction of Tiphsah by Menahem teach about the consequences of harsh leadership and lack of compassion?
options: Cruelty leads to suffering and is condemned by God
Harshness is necessary to maintain order
Violence against innocents is a sign of wisdom
Leaders should prioritize power over mercy
questions.correctAnswer: Cruelty leads to suffering and is condemned by God
questions.explanation: Menahem’s brutal attack on Tiphsah, including harming pregnant women (2 Kings 15:16), exemplifies cruelty and injustice, teaching believers to lead with compassion and integrity.

questions.question: A believer is questioning how to maintain integrity in leadership. Based on Jotham’s building of the higher gate of the LORD’s house, what principle can be shared about serving God in church life and fellowship?
options: Serving God includes contributing to the community and God’s house
Service is optional and unrelated to faith
questions.correctAnswer: Serving God includes contributing to the community and God’s house
questions.explanation: Jotham built the higher gate of the LORD’s house (2 Kings 15:35), showing that leadership involves active service and stewardship in the community of faith, encouraging believers to serve others.

questions.question: True or False: The chapter teaches that trusting in God alone without alliances is always the safest path, as demonstrated by Israel's experience with Assyria.
questions.explanation: Israel’s kings often made alliances, such as Menahem paying tribute to Pul king of Assyria (2 Kings 15:19-20), which led to temporary peace but at great cost, showing the complexity and risks rather than a simple truth about trust.

questions.question: How does the pattern of kingship in Israel during this chapter teach about the importance of honesty and integrity in daily life?
options: Kings who did evil faced conspiracies and downfall
Integrity is not important for leaders
questions.correctAnswer: Kings who did evil faced conspiracies and downfall
questions.explanation: Frequent conspiracies and murders (2 Kings 15:10, 15:14, 15:25, 15:30) show consequences of evil leadership, teaching believers the importance of honesty and integrity to avoid destructive outcomes.

questions.question: What does the chronicling of the kings’ deeds in the "book of the chronicles" suggest about accountability and recording our spiritual lives?
options: Our actions are remembered and have lasting significance
No one cares about our deeds
Only kings have their actions recorded
questions.correctAnswer: Our actions are remembered and have lasting significance
questions.explanation: The repeated mention of the "book of the chronicles" (e.g., 2 Kings 15:6, 15:11, 15:15) reveals that leaders are accountable and their deeds recorded, encouraging believers to live with integrity and faithfulness.

questions.question: A believer feels discouraged by partial success in obedience. How does Azariah and Jotham’s example encourage contentment and ongoing faithfulness?
options: They did right in the Lord’s sight but did not fully remove high places
They perfectly obeyed God without fail
questions.correctAnswer: They did right in the Lord’s sight but did not fully remove high places
questions.explanation: Both Azariah and Jotham are noted for doing right but leaving high places intact (2 Kings 15:4, 15:35), teaching believers to be faithful in what they can do while continuing to grow.

hard.title: 2 Kings Chapter 15 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Kings Chapter 15.

questions.question: According to 2 Kings 15, what significant physical ailment afflicted King Azariah (Uzziah), and what was the consequence of this condition?
options: He was struck with blindness and could not see his people
He was smitten with leprosy and dwelt in a separate house
He became deaf and was unable to hear counsel
He was paralyzed and confined to his bed
questions.correctAnswer: He was smitten with leprosy and dwelt in a separate house
questions.explanation: Verse 2 Kings 15:5 states that the LORD smote King Azariah so that he was a leper until the day of his death, and he lived in a separate house.

questions.question: What persistent religious practice did Azariah fail to eliminate during his reign, as noted in 2 Kings 15?
options: High places where sacrifices and incense were offered
questions.correctAnswer: High places where sacrifices and incense were offered
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:4 and 15:35 mention that Azariah and his son Jotham did not remove the high places, and the people continued to sacrifice and burn incense there.

questions.question: Which king of Assyria came against Israel during Menahem's reign, prompting Menahem to pay a large tribute?
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:19 records that Pul king of Assyria came against the land and Menahem gave him a thousand talents of silver to confirm his kingdom.

questions.question: How long did Shallum son of Jabesh reign over Israel before he was killed, according to 2 Kings 15?
questions.explanation: Verse 2 Kings 15:13 specifies that Shallum reigned a full month in Samaria before being killed.

questions.question: Which son of Jeroboam began to reign in Israel during the thirty-eighth year of Azariah king of Judah, as recorded in 2 Kings 15?
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:8 states that Zachariah son of Jeroboam reigned over Israel for six months during the thirty-eighth year of Azariah's reign.

questions.question: What was the repeated sin of the kings of Israel mentioned throughout 2 Kings 15, associated with Jeroboam son of Nebat?
options: Following the sins that caused Israel to sin, including idolatry at high places
Failing to pay tribute to Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: Following the sins that caused Israel to sin, including idolatry at high places
questions.explanation: Verses such as 2 Kings 15:9, 15:18, 15:24, and 15:28 emphasize that the kings of Israel did evil and did not depart from the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat, which led Israel into sin.

questions.question: Which king of Israel conspired against and killed Pekah son of Remaliah, according to 2 Kings 15?
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:30 describes how Hoshea son of Elah conspired against Pekah, killed him, and reigned in his place.

questions.question: True or False: Jotham, son of Uzziah, was known for completely removing the high places and idol worship during his reign.
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:35 clearly states that Jotham did not remove the high places; the people still sacrificed and burned incense there.

questions.question: What literary device is evident in the repeated phrase throughout 2 Kings 15 noting that the acts of each king are recorded in 'the book of the chronicles of the kings'?
questions.explanation: The repeated statement about the acts of each king being recorded in the chronicles (e.g., 2 Kings 15:6, 11, 15, 21, 26, 31, 36) serves as a literary refrain, emphasizing historical record-keeping.

questions.question: What is the significance of Menahem's violent act against Tiphsah and its inhabitants, especially the pregnant women, as described in 2 Kings 15?
options: It was a justified military tactic sanctioned by the LORD
It foreshadowed the brutal Assyrian oppression that Israel would face
It showed mercy to the defeated city
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadowed the brutal Assyrian oppression that Israel would face
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:16 describes Menahem's ruthless attack, which reflects the harsh realities of Near Eastern warfare and prefigures Assyrian cruelty toward Israel.

questions.question: What does the prophecy cited in 2 Kings 15:12 regarding Jehu's descendants indicate about the dynastic continuity of Israel's throne?
options: That Jehu's sons would never reign
That Jehu's sons would sit on the throne for four generations
That Jehu's dynasty would end immediately
That Jehu was not a legitimate king
questions.correctAnswer: That Jehu's sons would sit on the throne for four generations
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:12 references the word of the LORD that Jehu's sons would sit on Israel's throne until the fourth generation, which occurred historically.

questions.question: Which king of Israel began his reign in Samaria in the twentieth year of Jotham son of Uzziah, marking a change in the northern kingdom leadership?
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:30 states that Hoshea began to reign in Israel in the twentieth year of Jotham's reign in Judah.

questions.question: How does the reign of Azariah (Uzziah) in 2 Kings 15 illustrate the theme of divine judgment intertwined with kingship in the Hebrew Bible?
options: His long reign without any divine consequence
His leprosy as a direct punishment from God while still having a son govern in his stead
His complete rejection by the people
questions.correctAnswer: His leprosy as a direct punishment from God while still having a son govern in his stead
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:5-7 shows that God struck Azariah with leprosy, a mark of divine judgment, yet his son Jotham governed during his affliction, reflecting the complex relationship between divine favor and kingship.

questions.question: Which two kings are mentioned in 2 Kings 15:37 as beginning to send threats against Judah during Jotham's reign?
options: Pul king of Assyria and Tiglathpileser king of Assyria
Rezin king of Syria and Pekah son of Remaliah
Menahem king of Israel and Shallum king of Israel
Hoshea king of Israel and Jeroboam king of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Rezin king of Syria and Pekah son of Remaliah
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:37 states that the LORD began to send against Judah Rezin king of Syria and Pekah son of Remaliah, signaling external threats.

questions.question: What was Jotham’s mother’s name, and how does this reflect the historical or cultural context of Judah’s royal family as mentioned in 2 Kings 15?
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:33 identifies Jotham’s mother as Jerusha, daughter of Zadok, reflecting the common practice of noting maternal lineage, often linked to priestly families like Zadok's.

theological.title: 2 Kings Chapter 15 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Kings Chapter 15 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to 2 Kings 15, what was notable about King Azariah's reign in relation to his obedience to God?
options: He did what was right, but did not remove the high places
He fully removed all high places and led Israel to repentance
He did evil in the sight of the LORD
He reigned only a short time with no significant actions
questions.correctAnswer: He did what was right, but did not remove the high places
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:3-4 states Azariah did right in the LORD's sight like his father Amaziah but did not remove the high places. This shows partial obedience, consistent with the biblical theme that incomplete obedience results in judgment (1 Kings 15:14; Exodus 20:24; Deuteronomy 12:2-3; 1 Samuel 15:22).

questions.question: What divine judgment did King Azariah suffer due to his actions?
options: He was struck with leprosy and lived separately until death
He lost his throne to his son immediately
questions.correctAnswer: He was struck with leprosy and lived separately until death
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:5 records that the LORD smote Azariah with leprosy, causing him to dwell in a separate house until death. This shows God's holiness and judgment on sin (Leviticus 13:45; Numbers 12:10; 2 Chronicles 26:19-21; Luke 5:12-14).

questions.question: Which king reigned for only six months before being assassinated according to 2 Kings 15?
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:8-10 states Zachariah reigned six months before Shallum conspired against and killed him. This brief reign illustrates the instability of Israel's monarchy due to sin and political violence (Psalm 75:6-7; Ecclesiastes 8:9; Proverbs 16:12; Romans 13:1).

questions.question: What promise did God make to Jehu regarding his descendants?
options: His sons would sit on Israel's throne for four generations
His descendants would never rule Israel
His line would be cursed forever
questions.correctAnswer: His sons would sit on Israel's throne for four generations
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:12 records God's word to Jehu that his sons would sit on Israel's throne until the fourth generation, affirming divine sovereignty over dynasties (Genesis 17:7; Exodus 34:7; 2 Samuel 7:12-16; Luke 1:32-33).

questions.question: How did Menahem secure his reign against the threat of Assyria?
options: By paying a thousand talents of silver to Pul, king of Assyria
By forming an alliance with Egypt
By leading a successful military campaign against Assyria
By marrying into the Assyrian royal family
questions.correctAnswer: By paying a thousand talents of silver to Pul, king of Assyria
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:19-20 describes Menahem paying Pul to confirm his reign, demonstrating the political reality of foreign influence and the consequences of Israel's sinfulness leading to subjugation (Isaiah 10:5-6; 2 Chronicles 28:16-21; Jeremiah 27:6; Romans 13:1).

questions.question: What horrific act did Menahem commit in the city of Tiphsah?
options: He ripped open all the pregnant women because they did not open the city to him
He destroyed the city's temple completely
He made an alliance with the city and spared it
He exiled all the inhabitants to Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: He ripped open all the pregnant women because they did not open the city to him
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:16 recounts Menahem's cruel act against Tiphsah's pregnant women, illustrating the brutal consequences of sin and rebellion, echoing themes of divine judgment through human violence (Genesis 34:25-29; Exodus 1:15-22; Jeremiah 19:9; Hosea 13:16).

questions.question: Which king was assassinated in the palace by a captain named Pekah?
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:25 identifies Pekahiah as being killed in the palace by Pekah, revealing the recurring theme of political intrigue and instability stemming from Israel's departure from God's ways (Psalm 2:2; 1 Kings 22:29-40; Proverbs 29:2; Romans 1:28-32).

questions.question: During whose reign did Tiglathpileser king of Assyria invade and carry many Israelites captive?
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:29 reports Tiglathpileser's conquest during Pekah's reign, signifying the fulfillment of prophetic warnings about Assyrian captivity as a judgment for Israel's sin (Isaiah 10:5-19; 2 Kings 17:6; Jeremiah 25:9; Luke 21:20-24).

questions.question: Who succeeded Pekah as king of Israel after conspiring against him?
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:30 declares Hoshea conspired against and killed Pekah. This continued cycle of conspiracies reflects Israel's persistent rejection of God's covenant leadership (Judges 21:25; 1 Samuel 8:7; Ezekiel 21:25-27; Romans 1:18-32).

questions.question: What was notable about King Jotham's reign in terms of obedience?
options: He did what was right but did not remove the high places
He completely removed all high places and led Judah back to God
He did evil throughout his reign
He ruled only a short time with no significant reforms
questions.correctAnswer: He did what was right but did not remove the high places
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:34-35 notes Jotham did right like his father Uzziah but did not remove high places, showing partial obedience and the ongoing problem of syncretism in Judah (2 Chronicles 27:2-6; Exodus 20:4-5; Jeremiah 7:31; Matthew 23:27-28).

questions.question: What foreign threat began to press against Judah during Jotham's reign?
options: Rezin king of Syria and Pekah king of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Rezin king of Syria and Pekah king of Israel
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:37 tells that Rezin and Pekah began to send forces against Judah, marking the rise of threats that would lead to future judgment and exile (Isaiah 7:1-9; 2 Chronicles 28:5-8; Micah 5:5; Romans 8:28).

questions.question: How old was Azariah when he began to reign, and how long did he reign in Jerusalem?
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:2 specifies Azariah began to reign at sixteen and ruled for fifty-two years, highlighting God's providence in a long reign despite his infirmity (Psalm 90:10; Ecclesiastes 3:1-2; Isaiah 38:5-6; Daniel 4:34-37).

questions.question: What was the name of Azariah's mother, and what significance might this have?
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:2 names Jecholiah as Azariah's mother, indicating royal lineage and the importance of maternal heritage in Judah's monarchy (1 Chronicles 3:11; Matthew 1:3; Luke 3:32; Proverbs 31:30).

questions.question: Which king built the higher gate of the house of the LORD according to 2 Kings 15?
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 15:35 states Jotham built the higher gate of the house of the LORD, reflecting his efforts to maintain and improve the temple despite incomplete reform, illustrating the ongoing tension between worship and idolatry (1 Kings 6:1-38; 2 Chronicles 27:3; Ezra 3:8; John 2:13-17).

questions.question: What recurring sin did many kings of Israel fail to depart from, as noted repeatedly in 2 Kings 15?
options: The sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat
questions.correctAnswer: The sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat
questions.explanation: Verses 9, 18, 24, and 28 repeatedly mention kings doing evil by not departing from Jeroboam's sins, which involved idolatry and apostasy, emphasizing the destructive power of covenant unfaithfulness (1 Kings 12:26-33; Hosea 4:17; Romans 1:21-32; Galatians 5:19-21).
